title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation owned by individuals age 55+, or partnership/trust/estate owned by individuals age 55+. Qualified agricultural property includes single purpose agricultural or horticultural property. Qualified agricultural property refers to specific structures, real property, equipment, or fixtures used for agricultural purposes. United States real property is defined as real estate located within the country. Property received in an exchange must be identified and completed within 180 days. The term 'United States real property' refers to real estate located in the country. Property received in an exchange must be identified within 45 days and completed within 180 days. The taxpayer must transfer the relinquished property by the due date for the tax return. Rules similar to section 1031 apply, and the transaction is treated as a section 1031 exchange. Ordinary income recapture is deferred until the disposition of real property acquired in the exchange. The taxpayer must transfer the relinquished property by the tax return due date. The transaction is treated as a section 1031 exchange. Gain from qualified agricultural property disposed of under section 1046 is not recognized until disposition. The gain taken into account by the transferor under subsection (a)(1) should not exceed the sum of the gain recognized on the disposition and the fair market value of property acquired that is not section 1245 property or United States real property. If United States real property acquired in an exchange is disposed of, the lesser of the gain recognized or ordinary income recapture applies. When United States real property acquired in an exchange is disposed of by the transferee, the gain recognized should not exceed the excess of the amount realized over the adjusted basis of the property. The gain recognized on the disposition of qualified agricultural property should not exceed the excess of the amount of gain treated as ordinary income if the property were sold at fair market value over the gain recognized on the disposition of any other real property. The gain recognized on the disposition of qualified agricultural property will be treated as ordinary income, regardless of any other provisions. The amendments apply to transfers and dispositions after the enactment of the Act. Special rules apply for installment sales of qualified agricultural property. Special rules apply for installment sales of qualified agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes a special rule where income from the installment sale is accounted for under the installment method, and income recognized for any taxable year from such sale shall be recognized accordingly. The installment method applies to income from installment sales, with recognized income being treated as recapture income in the same proportion as the aggregate recapture income to the aggregate income from the sale. A conforming amendment is made to section 453(i) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment of this Act.
